awd_titl_txt: Organization and Dynamics in Photosynthetic Reaction Centers and Model Membrane Architectures
awd_abstract_narration:
Photosynthetic reaction center (RC) is a remarkable machine that absorbs light and transfers electrons across a biological membrane.  Membranes are very thin insulators, so this process is like charging a capacitor.  Once charged, the capacitor discharges by driving the biosynthesis of stable energetic molecules or fuels.  All life on earth depends on this process.  This research will lead to a better understanding of the mechanisms by which photosynthetic reaction centers harvest and store solar energy, and the development of model membrane assemblies that mimic natural biological membranes and their interactions.  This project will modulate the properties of key amino acids near to the reactive chromophores in the RC to systematically understand why electrons take the pathway they do and by what precise mechanism.   A significant part of this work involves the development of new experimental and theoretical methods that will have a broad impact in other areas of science and technology. This research program will continue to support the development of a generation of young scientists with diverse backgrounds, primarily graduate students, who go on to productive careers at the interface of the physical sciences and biology, biotechnology, and energy-related science.

This project focuses on two related topics; the mechanism of charge separation in bacterial photosynthetic reaction centers, and the development of novel methods to assemble and image model membrane architectures. This project will implement site specific modification of functionally important amino acids with non-canonical amino acids and the introduction of nitrile spectator probes for electron transfer and membrane potential. This project will continue development of a "membrane interferometer", designed for simultaneous optical and electrical measurements on single integral membrane proteins such as ion channels, and develop novel methods to measure lipid diffusion on sub-micron sized membranes to explore the effects of curvature on diffusion. This project is supported by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Biological Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

We seek to understand how the organized environment in proteins modulates the spectroscopic and redox properties of bound prosthetic groups like chlorophylls, hemes and retinals, with important functional consequences. While focused on photosynthetic reaction centers (RCs), the concepts and approaches can be applied to any organized biological system. A significant part of this work involves the development of new experimental and theoretical methods, and these can have a broad impact in other areas of science and technology. Nearly every spectroscopic, structural, and theoretical method has been applied to some aspect of photosynthesis research. In many cases a question related to photosynthetic function stimulated the first application of a physical method to a biological problem, which then impacted other areas of biophysical research and other disciplines.  These concepts and techniques have spun off complementary research programs in our lab and many others.

The RC is the minimal assembly of chlorophylls, quinones and proteins needed to achieve the initial light-driven charge steps of photosynthesis.  As a protein assembly associated with a biological membrane, the RC’s function is to separate charge across the membrane in response to light, much like charging a capacitor; this capacitor is then discharged by reactions that take place in the dark and lead to the synthesis of ATP, the energy currency of cells. While the primary sequence of the RC has been extensively manipulated by site-directed mutagenesis, we sought to expand the scope of possible changes by using amber suppression to introduce non-canonical amino acids.  We have used this to selectively perturb the initial electron transfer steps and provide insight into the mechanism by which light is converted into separated charge.  We have also used advanced imaging mass spectrometry methods to obtain information on the sub-micron scale organization of lipids in model biological membranes.  While such organization is generally believed to exist, at least locally, and is the key to many biological functions, these new methods provide the first direct information on this organization.  Lastly, in collaboration with Noah Burns’ group, we have studied the self-assembly of highly unusual lipids that are not available commercially but are found in a significant number of non-mammalian organisms.  This has led to the discovery of assemblies that may be useful for drug delivery.

Broader impact

Sustained support from NSF has greatly impacted the training of several generations of scientists with diverse backgrounds, primarily graduate students, all of whom have gone on to productive careers at the interface of the physical sciences and biology, biotechnology, and energy-related science.  The work has been presented in many invited talks and at workshops, including ones that reach out to diverse communities and government agencies looking to future directions in nanoscience, biotechnology and energy-related science.  The PI has developed a new course in Biophysical Chemistry for senior Chemistry majors and, due to high demand, a parallel course for first year graduate students. Both are based entirely on the primary literature and provide an in-depth discussion of current frontiers and controversies in biophysics firmly grounded in the physical sciences. Photosynthesis remains a topic of deep interest to a wide community of scientist and engineers, both because of fundamental questions raised and the potential to exploit natural photosynthesis or possibly create or inspire artificial photosynthetic systems.
